skill.name: internal-comms
skill.description: A set of resources to help me write all kinds of internal communications, using the formats that my company likes to use. Claude should use this skill whenever asked to write some sort of internal communications (status reports, leadership updates, 3P updates, company newsletters, FAQs, incident reports, project updates, etc.).
skill.summary: A set of resources to help me write all kinds of internal communications, using the formats that my ...
skill.author: Anthropic

security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill containing only markdown documentation files with internal communications templates. No executable code, no external dependencies, no security risks identified.

content.value_statement: Helps you write professional internal company communications like team updates, newsletters, and FAQs using proven templates and best practices.
actual_capabilities: Write 3P updates (Progress, Plans, Problems) for teams of any size
Create company-wide newsletter summaries with 20-25 bullet points
Generate FAQ responses based on common employee questions
Draft status reports and leadership updates
Format communications with consistent structure and tone
Integrate with company tools (Slack, Google Drive, Email, Calendar) when available
limitations: Requires user input or tool access to gather actual company information
Cannot access company systems without proper integrations
Templates are specific to certain communication formats (3P, newsletter, FAQ, general)
Assumes certain company communication culture and norms
Best suited for companies with 100+ employees for newsletter format

use_cases.title: Weekly Team 3P Update
use_cases.description: Create a concise Progress/Plans/Problems update for a team to share with leadership and stakeholders, covering the past week's accomplishments, next week's priorities, and current blockers.
use_cases.target_user: Team leads, engineering managers, product managers

use_cases.title: Company-Wide Newsletter
use_cases.description: Compile a comprehensive weekly or monthly newsletter summarizing major company announcements, product updates, leadership posts, and external press for the entire organization.
use_cases.target_user: Internal communications teams, executive assistants, chiefs of staff

use_cases.title: Employee FAQ Responses
use_cases.description: Identify frequently asked questions across the company and provide clear, authoritative answers to reduce confusion and improve alignment.
use_cases.target_user: People ops, internal comms, executive teams

use_cases.title: Custom Internal Communications
use_cases.description: Draft any other internal communication that doesn't fit standard formats, with guidance on audience, tone, and structure.

prompt_templates.title: Generate Weekly 3P Update
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a 3P update for the [team name] team covering [date range]. Include progress on [project/milestone], plans for [upcoming work], and problems related to [blockers/challenges].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to quickly summarize your team's week for leadership

prompt_templates.title: Create Company Newsletter
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a company newsletter for the past week. Include announcements about [topic 1], updates on [topic 2], and highlights from [team/department].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to compile weekly company updates for all employees

prompt_templates.title: Answer Common Questions
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate FAQ answers for questions employees are asking about [topic/announcement]. Base answers on [source documents/announcements].
prompt_templates.scenario: When there's confusion after a major announcement or change

best_practices: Always confirm team name and time period before writing 3P updates
Keep communications concise and data-driven with specific metrics
Use available tools (Slack, Google Drive, Email, Calendar) to gather information rather than guessing
Match the existing company communication style and tone
Focus on company-wide impact for newsletters, not team-specific details
Link to authoritative sources when answering FAQs
Follow strict formatting guidelines for each communication type
Prioritize information that affects the broadest audience
Use the 'we' tense for company newsletters to foster inclusivity
anti_patterns: Writing 3P updates without knowing the team name
Including overly granular details in company-wide newsletters
Making up metrics or information without tool access or user input
Using inconsistent formatting that doesn't match templates
Answering FAQs without linking to official sources
Writing prose-heavy updates instead of concise, data-driven summaries
Focusing on small team updates in company newsletters
Including information that's only relevant to small groups

faq.question: What does 3P stand for?
faq.answer: 3P stands for Progress, Plans, Problems - a structured format for team updates covering what was accomplished, what's planned next, and what blockers exist.

faq.question: How long should each section of a 3P update be?
faq.answer: Each section (Progress, Plans, Problems) should be 1-3 sentences maximum. The entire update should be readable in 30-60 seconds.

faq.question: Can this skill access my company's Slack or Google Drive?
faq.answer: Only if you have those tools integrated and available. Otherwise, the skill will ask you to provide information directly or inform you that results would be better with tool access.

faq.question: What if my communication doesn't fit the 3P, newsletter, or FAQ format?
faq.answer: Use the general-comms template which will ask about your audience, purpose, tone, and formatting requirements before drafting custom internal communications.

faq.question: How many bullet points should a company newsletter have?
faq.answer: Approximately 20-25 bullet points organized into logical sections like Company Announcements, Progress on Priorities, Leadership Updates, etc.
